channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: DOJ moves to dismiss police consent decrees in Louisville and Minneapolis
item.description: The DOJ announced it will drop lawsuits against Louisville and Minneapolis that would have required them to address what the Biden administration found to be widespread patterns of police misconduct.

item.title: Trump shows South Africa's Ramaphosa a video montage in tense Oval Office meeting
item.description: President Trump meets in the Oval Office with South African President Cyril Ramaphosa. Bilateral relations are at their lowest since the end of apartheid.

item.title: Russia sent novice spies to Brazil. Then Brazil exposed them
item.description: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly talks with Jane Bradley of The New York Times about her investigation with Michael Schwirtz into Brazil's unmasking of Russian spies in their midst.

item.title: 'The Trouble With Heroes' explores the healing power of hiking
item.description: Kate Messner's new middle grade novel The Trouble With Heroes Is about a boy who gets into trouble with the law. Instead of juvie, he's tasked with hiking all 46 Adirondack peaks.

item.title: Broadway's Jonathan Groff on what motivated him to come out early in his career
item.description: On Wild Card, well-known guests answer the kinds of questions we often think about but don't talk about. Broadway star Jonathan Groff reflects on what motivated him to come out early in his career.

item.title: Tariffs on flowers likely mean higher prices, but opportunity for local farmers
item.description: The U.S. imports many of its flowers, plants and nursery products from countries like Ecuador, Colombia and Canada. Tariffs may drive up prices. It may mean more opportunity for local flower farmers.

item.title: Doors singer Jim Morrison's bust recovered in France
item.description: A decades-old mystery involving Jim Morrison of The Doors has been (somewhat) solved. The singer's bust was stolen from a Paris cemetery in the 1980s. Authorities have found it in a separate probe.

item.title: A Newark air traffic controller on how it felt when systems went dark
item.description: An air traffic controller who works the airspace around Newark, N.J. talks about what it was like to lose radar and communication systems during a shift, and how the situation got to be so bad.

item.title: Former Secret Service agent describes fugitive search efforts
item.description: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly talks with Donald Lane, a former Secret Service agent, on what it takes to execute a manhunt and apprehend a fugitive.

item.title: GAO has long done DOGE-like work
item.description: Experts say DOGE should have paid closer attention to the Government Accountability Office, which has long worked to root out waste, fraud and abuse in the federal government.
